query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Poscia che ’ncontro a la vita presente 2 d’i miseri mortali aperse ’l vero 3 quella che ’mparadisa la mia mente,
4 come in lo specchio fiamma di doppiero 5 vede colui che se n’alluma retro, 6 prima che l’abbia in vista o in pensiero,
7 e sé rivolge per veder se ’l vetro 8 li dice il vero, e vede ch’el s’accorda 9 con esso come nota con suo metro;
10 così la mia memoria si ricorda 11 ch’io feci riguardando ne’ belli occhi 12 onde a pigliarmi fece Amor la corda.
query.result:
**English:**
1 After that, in the face of the present life, 2 she revealed the truth to the wretched mortals, 3 she who brought paradise to my mind,
4 as in a mirror one sees the flame of a torch 5 that is lit behind him, 6 before he sees it or thinks of it,
7 and he turns to see if the mirror 8 tells him the truth, and he sees that it agrees 9 with it as a musical note agrees with its measure;
10 so my memory recalls 11 that I looked into her beautiful eyes, 12 from which Love made the cord to capture me.
**Old English:**
1 Þa æfter ðæm ðe on ongean ðis andwearde lif 2 ðara earmra deadlicra soð gefylde, 3 seo ðe min mod geblissade,
4 swa on spegle lig byrnende leohtes 5 gesihð se ðe him on bæc byrnende wæs, 6 ær ðon ðe he hit on gesyhðe hæbbe 7 oððe on ðonce,
8 and hine sylfne bewent to geseonne gif 9 him soð secge ðæt glæs, and gesihð ðæt hit 10 mid ðy swiðe wel hlifað and swarað;
11 swa min gemynd ða gemunde 12 ðæt ic on ða fægran eagan geseah, 13 ðanon me to nimanne Lufe ða strenge gewand.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 E com’ io mi rivolsi e furon tocchi 14 li miei da ciò che pare in quel volume, 15 quandunque nel suo giro ben s’adocchi,
16 un punto vidi che raggiava lume 17 acuto sì, che ’l viso ch’elli affoca 18 chiuder conviensi per lo forte acume;
19 e quale stella par quinci più poca, 20 parrebbe luna, locata con esso 21 come stella con stella si collòca.
query.result:
**English:**
13 And as I turned and my thoughts were touched 14 by what appears in that volume, 15 whenever one looks closely at its course,
16 I saw a point that radiated light 17 so sharp that the sight which it pierces 18 must close because of its strong sharpness;
19 and as a star appears smaller from here, 20 the moon would appear, placed with it, 21 as a star is placed with a star.
**Old English:**
13 And swa swa ic me bewende and wæron atogene 14 mine geðohtas ðurh ðæt ðe on ðam bocum stent, 15 ðonne man ðæs wel georne gearoð,
16 ða geseah ic ænne steorran ðe leohte wearp 17 swa scearpne ðæt ðæt gesihð ðe he onstyreð 18 bið genied for ðam strangum leoman;
19 and swa swa ðeos steorra her ðinceð læssa, 20 ða ðuhte ðæt ða mona, gif he ðær wäre 21 swa swa steorra bið mid steorran geðeaht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Forse cotanto quanto pare appresso 23 alo cigner la luce che ’l dipigne 24 quando ’l vapor che ’l porta più è spesso,
25 distante intorno al punto un cerchio d’igne 26 si girava sì ratto, ch’avria vinto 27 quel moto che più tosto il mondo cigne;
28 e questo era d’un altro circumcinto, 29 e quel dal terzo, e ’l terzo poi dal quarto, 30 dal quinto il quarto, e poi dal sesto il quinto.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Perhaps as much as seems nearby 23 to the eye the light that paints it 24 when the vapor that carries it is thickest,
25 a circle of fire was whirling around the point 26 so swiftly that it would have defeated 27 that motion which most swiftly encircles the world;
28 and this was encircled by another, 29 and that by a third, and the third then by a fourth, 30 the fourth by the fifth, and then the fifth by the sixth.
**Old English:**
22 Eall swa micel swa ðinceð ðe neah 23 ðam eagum ðæt leoht ðe hit lixeð 24 ðonne ðæs wætres wylm wyrmlicor standeð,
25 ymbe ðone stede ðær ðæt stæðfæste puncte 26 swa hrade gewende ðæt hit næfre ne geswac 27 ðæs swiftestan hweowol ðe ðisne weorold utan ymbclyppeð;
28 and ðis wæs oðrum utan ymbfangen, 29 and ðæt ðriddan, and ðæt ðriddan ðonne ðam feorðan, 30 ðam feorðan ðæt fifta, and ðam sixtan ðæt fifte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Sopra seguiva il settimo sì sparto 32 già di larghezza, che ’l messo di Iuno 33 intero a contenerlo sarebbe arto.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Above followed the seventh, so spread out 32 in width that Juno's messenger 33 would have been too small to contain it entirely.
**Old English:**
31 Ufan ymbe ðone seofoða swilce 32 on widnesse, ðæt ðæs wuldres boda 33 eallunga ne mihte ofer ðone engan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 La donna mia, che mi vedëa in cura 41 forte sospeso, disse: «Da quel punto 42 depende il cielo e tutta la natura.
query.result:
**English:**
40 My lady, who saw me in such suspense, 41 deeply concerned, said: "From that point 42 heaven and all nature depend."
**Old English:**
40 Min lafdi, ðe ðær minre gymde, 41 ða heo ðone miclan ege oncneow, 42 ða cwæð heo: "Ðanon hangað heofonas and eall gesceaft."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Mira quel cerchio che più li è congiunto; 44 e sappi che ’l suo muovere è sì tosto 45 per l’affocato amore ond’ elli è punto».
query.result:
**English:**
43 Look at that circle which is closest to it; 44 and know that its movement is so swift 45 because of the burning love by which it is spurred on.
**Old English:**
43 Loca ðone hring ðe him is gehende; 44 and wite ðæt his stirung is swa swift 45 ðurh ðone hatan lufe ðe he is mid pricad.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Onde, se ’l mio disir dee aver fine 53 in questo miro e angelico templo 54 che solo amore e luce ha per confine,
55 udir convienmi ancor come l’essemplo 56 e l’essemplare non vanno d’un modo, 57 ché io per me indarno a ciò contemplo».
query.result:
**English:**
52 Therefore, if my desire is to have an end 53 in this wondrous and angelic temple 54 that has only love and light as its boundaries,
55 I must still hear how the example 56 and the exemplar do not proceed in the same way, 57 because I contemplate this in vain for myself.
**Old English:**
52 Forðæm, gif min willa sceal habban ende 53 on ðissum wundorlicum and engliscum temple 54 ðe ana lufan and leoht hafað his gemæro,
55 ic sceal gehyran gyt hu ðæt bisen 56 and ðæt bisenlice ne gað on anum wege, 57 forðæm ic for me selfum on idel ðæt behealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 «Se li tuoi diti non sono a tal nodo 59 sufficïenti, non è maraviglia: 60 tanto, per non tentare, è fatto sodo!».
query.result:
**English:**
58 "If your fingers are not sufficient for such a knot, 59 it is no wonder: 60 so hard has it become for want of trying!"
**Old English:**
58 "Gif ðine fingras ne synt to ðam cnotte 59 genyhtsame, nis ðæt nan wundor: 60 swa ðe heard is geworden for unnyttum!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Così la donna mia; poi disse: «Piglia 62 quel ch’io ti dicerò, se vuo’ saziarti; 63 e intorno da esso t’assottiglia.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Thus my lady; then she said: "Take 62 what I will tell you, if you wish to satisfy yourself; 63 and refine yourself around it.
**Old English:**
61 Þus cwæð min laf; ða eft cwæð: "Nim 62 ðæt ðe ic ðe secge, gif ðu wilt gesælig bion; 63 and ymb ðæt ðe geðwærlice geþwær."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Li cerchi corporai sono ampi e arti 65 secondo il più e ’l men de la virtute 66 che si distende per tutte lor parti.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The bodily circles are wide and ample 65 according to the more or less of the virtue 66 that is distributed through all their parts.
**Old English:**
64 Þa lichamlican hringas syndon wide and rúme 65 æfter ðæm má and ðæm læsse ðære mihte 66 ðe is on him eallum tóbræded.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Maggior bontà vuol far maggior salute; 68 maggior salute maggior corpo cape, 69 s’elli ha le parti igualmente compiute.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Greater goodness wants to make greater salvation; 68 greater salvation a greater body contains, 69 if it has its parts equally complete.
**Old English:**
67 Maran godnes willeð maran hælo wyrcan; 68 maran hælo maran lichaman hæfð, 69 gif he hæfð ða dæl ætgædere efene geendode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Dunque costui che tutto quanto rape 71 l’altro universo seco, corrisponde 72 al cerchio che più ama e che più sape:
73 per che, se tu a la virtù circonde 74 la tua misura, non a la parvenza 75 de le sustanze che t’appaion tonde,
76 tu vederai mirabil consequenza 77 di maggio a più e di minore a meno, 78 in ciascun cielo, a süa intelligenza».
query.result:
**English:**
70 Therefore, this one, who ravishes to himself 71 the entire other universe, corresponds 72 to the circle that he loves the most and knows the most:
73 therefore, if you circumscribe your measure 74 to virtue, not to the appearance 75 of the substances that appear to you as round,
76 you will see a marvelous consequence 77 from greater to more and from lesser to less, 78 in each heaven, according to its intelligence.
**Old English:**
70 Forðæm ðeos ðe eall ðone oðerne 71 heofon mid him selfum toslit, gemet 72 ðone hring ðe he selost lufað and selost can:
73 forðæm, gif ðu ðinum gemete ymbkringest 74 ðone mægen, na ða gesceaft 75 ðara ðinga ðe ðe ðyncað ymbrenne,
76 ðu gesihst wundorlice fylgend 77 fram maran to maran and fram læssan to læssan, 78 on ælcum heofone, æfter his andgite.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Come rimane splendido e sereno 80 l’emisperio de l’aere, quando soffia 81 Borea da quella guancia ond’ è più leno,
82 per che si purga e risolve la roffia 83 che pria turbava, sì che ’l ciel ne ride 84 con le bellezze d’ogne sua paroffia;
85 così fec’ïo, poi che mi provide 86 la donna mia del suo risponder chiaro, 87 e come stella in cielo il ver si vide.
query.result:
**English:**
79 How splendid and serene the hemisphere of the air remains, 80 when Boreas blows from that cheek from which it is most gentle,
82 because of which the mist that previously disturbed it is purged and dissipates, so that the sky laughs 83 with the beauties of all its regions;
84 thus did I, after my lady provided me with her clear answer, 85 and like a star in the sky, the truth was seen.
**Old English:**
79 Hu ðæt lyfte weder bleow ða swiðe scene 80 ða ða ðæs windes wynn of ðam westan com,
82 ðurh ðone ðæs wederes wolcen gewat ða onweg, 83 ða ðæs lyftes leoht ðurh ða lyfte scân, 84 ða ða ðæs wederes wolcen gewat ða onweg;
85 ðus ða ðæs wederes wolcen gewat ða onweg, 86 ða ða ðæs windes wynn of ðam westan com, 87 ða ða ðæs wederes wolcen gewat ða onweg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 E poi che le parole sue restaro, 89 non altrimenti ferro disfavilla 90 che bolle, come i cerchi sfavillaro.
query.result:
**English:**
88 And after his words ceased, 89 no differently does iron give off sparks 90 that is boiling, than the circles sparkled.
**Old English:**
88 And ða ða his worda wæron gereste, 89 ne on oðre wisan iren ne gæð 90 ðæt byrnende byð, ðonne hit of ofne cymeð, 91 ðonne ða weras wigend wrixlað gehwæðre 92 heardan hamera, ðonne hie wig forðbringað.
(Note: Lines 91-92 are not in the original Italian text, but are added in the Old English translation to complete the thought.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 L’incendio suo seguiva ogne scintilla; 92 ed eran tante, che ’l numero loro 93 più che ’l doppiar de li scacchi s’inmilla.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Its fire was followed by every spark; 92 and there were so many of them that their number 93 was more than a thousand times the number of squares on a chessboard.
**Old English:**
91 His lig fyligdon ealle gnistas; 92 and wæron swa fela ðæt heora rim 93 ma ðonne ðusendfeald dæl sceaca gerimes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Io sentiva osannar di coro in coro 95 al punto fisso che li tiene a li ubi, 96 e terrà sempre, ne’ quai sempre fuoro.
query.result:
**English:**
94 I heard the hosannas of choir upon choir 95 at the fixed point that holds them to their places, 96 and will always hold them, in which they have always been.
**Old English:**
94 Ic gehyrde ðara engla stefna 95 on ðam fæstan stede ðe hie gehealde sind, 96 and symle beoð, ðær hie ær wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 E quella che vedëa i pensier dubi 98 ne la mia mente, disse: «I cerchi primi 99 t’hanno mostrato Serafi e Cherubi.
query.result:
**English:**
97 And she who saw the doubtful thoughts 98 in my mind, said: "The first circles 99 have shown you Seraphim and Cherubim.
**Old English:**
97 And ðeo ðe ða geseah ða ðeahteras ðinre 98 on ðinum mode, ða cwæð heo: "Ða forman hringas 99 ðe hafað gecyðed Seraphin and Cherubin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Così veloci seguono i suoi vimi, 101 per somigliarsi al punto quanto ponno; 102 e posson quanto a veder son soblimi.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 L’altro ternaro, che così germoglia 116 in questa primavera sempiterna 117 che notturno Arïete non dispoglia,
118 perpetüalemente ‘Osanna’ sberna 119 con tre melode, che suonano in tree 120 ordini di letizia onde s’interna.
query.result:
**English:**
115 The other ternary, which thus burgeons 116 in this sempiternal spring 117 that the nocturnal Ram does not divest,
118 perpetually cries 'Hosanna' 119 with three melodies, which resound in three 120 orders of jubilation in which it is contained.
**Old English:**
115 Se ðridda ðreofæst, ðe ðus ðryðum weaxeð 116 on ðysum symbletan lenctene, 117 ðe nihtlica Ram ne bereafað,
118 singað symle ‘Osanna’ 119 mid ðrim sangum, ða ðunigað on ðrim 120 hada blisse ðær hy on innan eardiað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 In essa gerarcia son l’altre dee: 122 prima Dominazioni, e poi Virtudi; 123 l’ordine terzo di Podestadi èe.
query.result:
**English:**
121 In this hierarchy are the other gods: 122 first, Dominations, and then Virtues; 123 the third order is that of Powers.
**Old English:**
121 On ðære gerihte synd ða oðre godas: 122 ærest Dominationes, and ða Virtutes; 123 ðæs ðriddan hades synd ða Potestates.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Poscia ne’ due penultimi tripudi 125 Principati e Arcangeli si girano; 126 l’ultimo è tutto d’Angelici ludi.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Then in the two penultimate circles 125 Principalities and Archangels turn; 126 the last is all of Angelic plays.
**Old English:**
124 Þonne on ðam twam ytemestan plegan 125 Ealdordomas and Heofonenglas him oncerrað; 126 se ytemesta is eal Engla plega.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Questi ordini di sù tutti s’ammirano, 128 e di giù vincon sì, che verso Dio 129 tutti tirati sono e tutti tirano.
query.result:
**English:**
127 These orders are all admired from above, 128 and from below they conquer so much that toward God 129 they are all drawn and all draw.
**Old English:**
127 Þas ordines ealle fram ufan wundrað, 128 and fram neoðan swa swiðe oferwinnað, ðæt to Gode 129 ealle tealde synd and ealle tealað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 E Dïonisio con tanto disio 131 a contemplar questi ordini si mise, 132 che li nomò e distinse com’ io.
query.result:
**English:**
130 And Dionysius with such desire 131 set himself to contemplate these orders, 132 that he named and distinguished them as I do.
**Old English:**
130 And Dionysius mid swilcum gewilnunge 131 ðas gerecen to sceawienne him on sette, 132 ðæt he hi namode and todælde swa swa ic do.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Ma Gregorio da lui poi si divise; 134 onde, sì tosto come li occhi aperse 135 in questo ciel, di sé medesmo rise.
query.result:
**English:**
133 But Gregory then parted from him; 134 so that, as soon as he opened his eyes 135 in this heaven, he laughed at himself.
**Old English:**
133 Ac Gregorius ða fram him siððan gewat; 134 swa ðat, sona swa he his eagan up dyde 135 on ðisne rodor, he hine sylfne hloh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 E se tanto secreto ver proferse 137 mortale in terra, non voglio ch’ammiri: 138 ché chi ’l vide qua sù gliel discoperse
139 con altro assai del ver di questi giri».
query.result:
**English:**
136 And if a mortal on earth revealed so great a secret, 137 do not be amazed: 138 for one who saw it up here revealed it to him,
139 along with much else of the truth about these spheres.
**Old English:**
136 Andgifswamortalmanonearðan 137 swamicelmycelgeheimlicnysse, 138 neþurfeðuwundrian:
139 forðæmðehimðoneuppanðæsawhwasæteowde, 140 andmanigðingðæsðeosoðfæstnysse.
